text: you
hi my name is Susan Laurie parks and I
am the book adapter I adapted the book
for the Gershwins Porgy and Bess
porgy and bess as you all probably know
is a great American masterpiece it's an
opera written in the 1930s and it's been
successful for many many many many many
years what seventy five seventy six
years the Gershwin estate approached us
a want date because they wanted to they
want to create a show a theatre piece
that is viable for the musical theater
stage so the original was an opera and
now we're charged with transforming it
into a musical a Broadway musical
I'm the book writer so I came on board
and I really saw my task as taking this
beautiful masterpiece approaching it
with love and respect and making it oh
more real more gritty more accessible to
contemporary audiences not dumbing it
down in any way but just making it just
more truthful to the african-american
experience in working with the Gershwins
Porgy and Bess and adapting the book
sometimes I would rewrite a scene or
sometimes just add a little bit of
dialogue sometimes I'd write something
that hadn't been there before for
example in with the song I got plenty of
nothing which for years has been a
really difficult song for a lot of
people to listen to it a lot of people
to sing because traditionally it's been
understood to be a song of the happy 99%
if you will you know our pockets are
empty but boy we're happy and I was like
you know there's gotta be more to that
and so I started thinking about the word
nothing and in the african-american
tradition nothing I mean nothing in
English you know you got like King Lear
you know nothing comes from nothing or
The Sound of Music nothing comes from
nothing but in the african-american
tradition the word nothing often is used
to mean everything or when you say
nothing you mean something so what I did
is I added some dialogue right before
the song in which Porgy comes out of the
house he's been living with best for
about a month he comes out of the house
and he said
good morning everybody and they say good
morning and they say wow porgy you're
looking better than good what you've
been up to and he says nothing
now all the men laugh and the audience
laughs - because nothing means something
means he's getting some love in his life
finally and so then he sings I got
plenty of nothing which now in our
production means I've got plenty of love
so I'd like to show you a piece of a
song sung by Norm Lewis and the cast of
the Gershwins Porgy and Bess
again I got my
